> No need to go off-list on this topic..I'd be interested too.  One
> connection you also may not know of is that Kennon was an undergrad
> here at UT and did an independent study with me working on NEAT a
> couple years ago. 
> 

And that independent study on NEAT was also what got me thinking about 
natural computation research, and thus this awesome year over here 
doing cool stuff and meeting 
great people (like Arjun).

So thanks, Ken, for the encouragement to pursue research as well as 
thinking up NEAT :)

> It's definitely interesting to know what the biggest researchers in
> neuroevolution are up to, since there really aren't that many major
> places to study this topic (yet).

I'd say that there is much more emphasis on methods like neuroevolution 
over here in the UK; quite a few of the CS departments here (sussex, 
edinburgh, UCL, etc) have people working on GAs and things like 
neuroevolution.

Sadly, I didn't qualify for the Overseas Research Scholarship (pretty much 
the only recourse for PhD funding for non UK/EU students here), so I'll be 
returning to the US this autumn. I'm hoping to start a phd in fall '05 
(since i missed the app deadlines for this next year). Any suggestions at 
universities in the US doing interesting work? (UT already turned me down 
once ... I wonder if I should reapply?)

Also, I'm hoping to find some position next year (fall '04) as a research 
assistant or something ... any suggestions about places that might hire 
non-phds?

-KB-
